title: Farewell to “Mr. Baseball”: The Legacy of Shigeo Nagashima

references.title: Baseball legend Shigeo Nagashima dies at 89

beats.text: A busy office freezes as a smartphone flashes an NHK breaking-news banner: “Shigeo Nagashima, national baseball icon, passes away at 89 on 3 June 2025.” The nerdy worker with glasses looks up, stunned—an era has ended. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
Who was he? Nicknamed “Mr. Baseball,” Nagashima embodied post-war Japan’s hopes, electrifying fans with charisma and clutch hitting for the Yomiuri Giants.

On the field he racked up a .305 batting average, 2,471 hits and 444 home runs, steering the Giants to nine straight Japan Series titles from 1965-73 alongside Sadaharu Oh. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

Switch to the dugout: in a swirl of chalk-board strategy doodles, manager Nagashima guides the team to dramatic championships in 1994 and 2000—his famous "Miracle V" grin says it all. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
A hospital corridor morphs into a recovery track: after a 2004 stroke, he battles through rehab, inspiring the nation while wearing his trademark Giants cap. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Final panel: fans leave carnations at Tokyo Dome, children re-enact his legendary swing. The narrator asks: How will Japan’s next generation carry forward the indomitable spirit of “Mr. Giants”?
